children.text: Standard 1: Students understand the unifying concepts and processes of science.
Models
Identify models (e.g., dolls, stuffed animals, toy vehicles) that are not real
Identify models that represent real objects (e.g., globe represents the Earth, doll represents a real baby)
Explain ways models are like (e.g., globe and Earth are both round) and unlike (e.g., different sizes, missing details and functions) real things
Explain changes in the real world using a model (e.g., erosion, volcano, stream table, wing designs for airplanes)
Use an appropriate model (e.g., drawing, equation, computer program, diagram, or 3-D device) to convey scientific information
Construct a model to represent concepts, features, or phenomena in the real world (e.g., solar system, earth's interior)
Explain how models can be used to illustrate scientific principles (e.g., osmosis, cell division)
Explain how models can be used to illustrate scientific principles
Explain how scientists create and use models to address scientific knowledge
Constancy and Change
Identify things that can change (e.g., weather, people, water)
Describe different ways that things can change (e.g., size, mass, color, movement)
Identify changes that are slow (e.g., human development) or fast (e.g., plant growth)
Identify changes that are repetitive (e.g., seasons, day and night, water cycle)
Identify changes that can be steady or irregular (e.g., floods, earthquakes, erosion, tooth decay)
Explain how changes alter the balance within a system (e.g., the effects of limited resources on populations, global climate change, flood, drought)
Explain the connection between cause and effect in a system
Identify examples of feedback mechanisms (e.g., hunger, perspiring)
Explain how a system can be dynamic yet may remain in equilibrium (e.g., water cycle, rock cycle, population)
Explain how a system can be dynamic yet may remain in equilibrium (e.g., balance of forces, Le Chatelier's Principle, acid base systems)
Systems
Identify objects (e.g., toy vehicles, dolls, human body, plants) that are made of parts

Identify some things that may not work if some of their parts are missing, broken, or assembled incorrectly (e.g., batteries are necessary for some toys to operate, wheels are necessary for a car to function)
Identify systems that are composed of subsystems (e.g., solar system, cell, ecosystems.)
Identify the components (e.g., tissues, organs, living and nonliving things) within a system (e.g., body systems, ecosystems)
Organize changes (e.g., patterns, cycles) that occur sequentially in systems
Describe the interaction of components within a system (e.g., interactions between living and nonliving components of an ecosystem, interaction between organelles of a cell)
Identify the structure, organization, and dynamics of components within a system (e.g., cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, reactants and products in chemical equilibrium)
Form and Function

Identify details of an object's form which determine its function (e.g., webbed feet for use in water, human feet for walking, shovel for scooping dirt, a rake for collecting leaves, tape measure and ruler to measure distance)
Identify the relationship between form and function (e.g., wings, fins and feet)
Describe the relationship between form and function (e.g., solids, liquids, gases, cell specialization, simple machines, and plate tectonics)
Explain how classification can be based on the relationship between form and function (e.g., elements and compounds, biological classifications, types of clouds)
Explain the relationship between form and function (e.g., atoms and ions, enzymes, aerodynamics)
11-12.1.5. Explain how classification can be based on the relationship between form and function (e.g., polar vs. nonpolar molecules, structure of periodic table , DNA vs. RNA)
Evolution and Equilibrium
Identify principles governing evolution and equilibrium within systems (e.g., cause and effect, positive and negative feedback)
Standard 2: Students use the process of science inquiry.
Abilities Necessary to do Scientific Inquiry
Use senses (i.e., sight, hearing, touch, smell, taste) to make observations about the world around them
Use simple tools (e.g., hand lens, balance, funnel, strainer) to extend the senses
Record and describe observations with pictures, numbers, or words
Ask questions and seek answers about the world (e.g., Why do we have seasons?)
Communicate (e.g., verbal, written, graphic) observations to others
Select appropriate scientific tools (i.e., magnifiers, thermometers, rulers, balances) for investigations
Ask questions directly related to a scientific investigation
Record observations (e.g., journals, drawings, charts) based on simple investigations
Review and ask questions about the scientific investigations of others
Conduct simple investigations to answer questions based on observations
Use scientific tools (i.e., thermometers, rulers, balances) during simple investigations
Communicate scientific procedures (e.g. visual display, graph, journal, oral presentation) that enable others to repeat the investigation
Formulate an explanation supported by data
Use appropriate tools and techniques to gather and analyze data
Use data from scientific investigations to determine relationships and patterns
Communicate the results of scientific investigations using an appropriate format (e.g., journals, lab reports, diagrams, presentations, discussions)
Use evidence to generate descriptions, explanations, predictions, and models
Use basic mathematics and statistics (e.g., operations, mean, median, mode, range, and estimation) to interpret quantitative data
Design and conduct a scientific investigation (e.g., making systematic observations, making accurate measurements, identifying and controlling variables)
Use appropriate safety equipment and precautions during investigations (e.g., goggles, apron, eye wash station)
Identify questions and concepts that guide scientific investigations
Formulate a testable hypothesis for a simple investigation
Identify the independent and dependent variables, the control, and the constants when conducting an experiment
Design and conduct a guided investigation
Maintain clear and accurate records of scientific investigations
Analyze data found in tables, charts, and graphs to formulate conclusions
Select and use appropriate instruments, measuring tools, and units of measure to improve scientific investigations
Use data from scientific investigations to accept or reject a hypothesis
Formulate and revise explanations based upon scientific knowledge and experimental data
Use technology and mathematics to improve investigations and communications
Analyze data using appropriate strategies (e.g., interpolation, and extrapolation of data, significant figures, dimensional analysis)
Design and conduct an independent investigation
Communicate and defend a scientific argument
Understandings About Scientific Inquiry
Explain the components of a scientific investigation (e.g., hypothesis, observation, data collection, data interpretation, communication of results, replicable)
Select alternative methods of scientific investigations (e.g., library, internet, field work) to address different kinds of questions.
Identify biases that may affect data collection and analysis (e.g., gender, race, religion, economic, generational.)
Explain how science advances through legitimate skepticism
Explain how scientific investigations can result in new ideas
Explain how new knowledge and methods emerge from different types of investigations and public communication among scientists
Standard 3: Students understand the basic concepts and principles of physical science.
Properties of Matter
Identify the materials that make up an object. (e.g., desk is made up of wood and metal, bike is made up of metal, rubber, and plastic)
Identify matter that can be a liquid or solid (e.g., water)
Identify observable properties (e.g., size, weight, shape, color, movement) of objects
Identify ways (e.g., mixing, heating, cooling, cutting) to make changes in matter
Explain why water left in an open container disappears, but water in a closed container does not disappear
Sort matter by observable properties (e.g., size, shape, texture, color)
Identify the physical properties of solids and liquids
Identify the forms in which water appears when heated and cooled (i.e., water vapor, liquid, solid)
Explain the relationship between the mass of an object and the sum of its parts.
Explain that matter is made up of parts that are too small to see without magnification
Identify physical properties of substances before and after they are combined
Identify new substances formed in a chemical change (i.e., rusting, burning)
Compare and contrast properties of solids, liquids, and gases
Organize materials according to similar properties (e.g., physical, chemical)
Identify elements and compounds
Explain the relationship between phases of matter and temperature
Classify elements according to similar properties. (e.g., metal, nonmetal, solids, liquids, gases)
Classify changes in matter as physical or chemical
Identify the Law of Conservation of Matter in physical and chemical changes
Force and Motion
Identify different kinds of motion (e.g., straight, circular, back-and-forth) that objects can have
Describe an object's location (e.g., further than, beside, under, over) relative to another object
Describe how objects fall unless something holds them up (e.g., apple on a tree, coat on a hook, pencil rolling off a desk)
Identify a force as push or pull
Describe how magnets attract iron and repel or attract other magnets
Identify the effects forces may have when applied to objects (i.e., start, stop, change direction)
Identify the effects force and mass have on the motion of an object
Explain why gravity is called an attracting force.
Use simple machines to change forces
Interpret the effect of balanced and unbalanced forces on the motion of an object (e.g., convection currents, orbital motion, tides)
Explain how all objects exert gravitational force and this force is affected by the distance between the masses of the objects
Use Newton's Laws to describe the motion of an object
Identify the principles and relationships influencing forces and motion (e.g., gravitational force, vectors, velocity, friction)
Forms of Energy
Identify whether sources of heat and light are natural or human-made (e.g., sunlight, light bulb)
Explain how sound is produced by vibration
Describe how the path of light tends to maintain its direction and motion until it encounters an object
Describe how the path of light changes (i.e., reflected, absorbed, or allowed to pass through) when it encounters a variety of objects
Explain how the pitch of a sound is related to the rate of vibrations.
Identify ways friction or burning produces heat (e.g., magnifying glass, carpet burn, sunburn)
Demonstrate a simple electrical circuit by completing a continuous loop (i.e., battery, light, wire)
Identify materials that are good conductors of heat
Identify different forms of energy (e.g., chemical, mechanical, heat, sound)
Identify sources of energy (e.g., sun, wind, moving water, nuclear, fossil fuels, food)
Explain the relationship among thermal energy, temperature, and the motion of particles
Vibrations and Waves
Explain how vibrations create wavelike disturbances that spread out from the source
Explain the characteristic properties (e.g., wavelength, frequency) and behaviors (e.g., reflection, refraction) of waves
Compare and contrast electromagnetic and mechanical waves (i.e. energy, energy transfer, medium)
Relate wave energy to wavelength and frequency
Energy Transfer and Transformation
Explain how forms of energy can be transferred. (e.g., photosynthesis, metabolism, battery)
Identify when heat can be transferred by conduction, convection, or radiation.
Describe the relationships between kinetic and potential energy in basic transformations (e.g., physical and chemical changes)
Apply the law of conservation of energy to a variety of situations
Explain how energy is related to physical changes of matter (e.g., phase changes, temperature changes)
Atoms and Molecules
Construct a model of an atom (e.g., protons, neutrons, electrons, nucleus, electron cloud)
Compare and contrast the role of electrons in ionic and covalent bonding
Identify the basic bonding characteristics of carbon which lead to a large variety of structures
Chemical Reactions
Identify the reactants and products in a chemical reaction
Distinguish between balanced and unbalanced chemical equations
Identify the effect of concentration, temperature, surface area, pressure, and catalysts on reaction rates as it relates to the Kinetic Theory.
Write the chemical formula and name for compounds using a table of element names, symbols, and oxidation numbers
Balance chemical equations
Electricity and Magnetism
Describe the differences between series and parallel circuits
Explain how magnetic forces relate to electric forces
Atomic Structure and Properties
Explain how the structure of an atom, isotope, or ion relates to its properties
Identify the basic organization of the periodic table (e.g., elements are listed according to the number of protons [atomic number]; repeating patterns of physical and chemical properties
Standard 4: Students understand the basic concepts and principles of life science.
Characteristics of Organisms
Identify animals eat plants or other animals for food
Identify plants and animals that closely resemble their parents and one another
Identify how plants and animals are alike and different (e.g., in the way they look, in their behaviors)
Identify behaviors of animals as instinctive or learned
Life Cycles
Identify characteristics of living things (e.g., grow, sometimes reproduce, change, and die over time)
Describe the life cycles of plants and animals (e.g., birds, mammals, grasses, trees, insects, flowers)
Organisms and Their Environments
Identify various things that are found in different environments (e.g., cactus, lizard â€“ desert; shark, coral- ocean)
Identify the needs of living things (e.g., food, shelter, soil, space, water)
Identify ways that an organism's pattern of behavior is related to the nature of the organism's environment (e.g., the availability of food, space, and resources)
Identify the producers, consumers, and decomposers in a food web.
Structure and Function
Identify parts of an organism that have specific functions (e.g., roots absorb water, heart pumps blood)
Classify plants and animals according to common physical characteristics
Identify adaptations that help plants and animals survive and grow in their environment
Identify components of a human organ system (e.g., digestive system, respiratory system, circulatory system, muscular system, skeletal system)
Explain the function of a human organ system (e.g., digestive system, respiratory system, circulatory system, muscular system, skeletal system)
Identify single- or multi-celled organisms.
Explain the functions of the cell (e.g., growth, metabolism, reproduction, photosynthesis, response)
Identify levels of organization in living systems (e.g., cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, organisms, ecosystems)
Relate cell function to cell structure (i.e., cell wall, cell membrane, nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplast)
Relate the functions of cells in multicellular organisms to their cell type (e.g., nerve cells, blood cells, guard cells)
Explain the relationship between protein structure and function
Explain the importance of cell differentiation in the development of tissues, organs, organ systems, and multicellular organisms.
Genetics and Reproduction
Explain why reproduction is necessary for the continuation of the species (e.g., asexual, sexual)
Identify the characteristics of reproduction (e.g., sexual, asexual)
Relate DNA, genes, and chromosomes
Explain the relationship between spontaneous changes in DNA and a source of genetic variation

Compare and contrast the results of mitosis and meiosis (i.e., mitosis involves a nuclear division that results in two daughter nuclei that are identical to the parent nucleus; meiosis involves two nuclear divisions that result in gametes cells containing half the number of chromosomes)
Apply the basic concepts of genetics to predict inherited traits (i.e., segregation, independent assortment, dominant and recessive traits)
Explain how types of DNA technology (e.g., genetic engineering, forensic science, cloning) may impact society now and in the future.
Interdependence Among Organisms
Identify interactions among organisms and their environment (e.g., competition, mutualism, predator/prey, consumers, producers)
Explain the energy and organization related to trophic pyramids
Diversity and Unity Among Organisms
Classify organisms (e.g., taxonomic groups)
Explain how different adaptations help organisms survive
Natural Selection and Biological Evolution
Identify the evidence of biological evolution. (e.g., adaptation, radiation, extinction) as found in the fossil record
Relate the concept of natural selection to its evolutionary consequences
Identify evidence for evolution (e.g., fossil records, vestigial structures, similarities between organisms, and DNA)
Explain how change through time has ensured adaptation to changing environments
Matter and Energy in Living Systems
Explain how matter and energy flow through living and nonliving components in an ecosystem (e.g., carbon cycle, water cycle, nitrogen cycle)
Compare and contrast photosynthesis and cellular respiration
Standard 5: Students understand the basic concepts and principles of earth and space science.
Weather, Seasons, and Climate
Describe day-to-day weather changes (e.g., sunny, rainy, cloudy, snowy)
Explain that short-term weather conditions can change daily, and how weather affects people's daily activities
Describe the patterns and characteristics of the four seasons, and how these changes in weather influence plant, animal, and human activities.
Identify weather conditions that can be measured (e.g., temperature, wind direction and speed, and precipitation)
Describe how as water condenses small droplets of water form clouds and fog
Measure weather conditions (i.e., temperature, wind direction and speed, and precipitation)
Identify characteristics of different clouds (i.e., cumulus, stratus, cirrus)
Identify adverse weather conditions and how humans prepare for them
Identify the factors (e.g., latitude, altitude, mountains, bodies of water) that affect the Earth's climate
Explain how seasons affect organisms (e.g., hibernation, photoperiodism, migration)
Explain how factors (i.e., fronts, winds, air masses, air pressure, humidity, temperature, location) affect weather
Earth's Surface
Identify different physical properties (e.g., size, shape, texture) of earth materials (e.g., rocks, sand, water)
Explain how fossils provide evidence about plants and animals and their environments that lived long ago (e.g., wooly mammoth, fern, ice age).
Identify different uses (e.g., building materials, sources of fuel) of Earth's materials based on their properties
Identify ways (e.g., wind, rain, people) that larger rocks break down into smaller rocks
Identify the properties of soil (e.g., color, texture, ability to support plant growth, capacity to retain water)
Identify slow and rapid processes (e.g., wind, water, waves, ice, volcano, earthquake) that are constantly changing Earth's surface
Use characteristics to classify Earth's materials (i.e. rocks, soil)
Compare fossil evidence to existing organisms
Identify how the components of soil (e.g., plant roots, bacteria, weathered rock) influence the properties of soil (e.g., texture, fertility, capacity to hold water)
Objects in the Sky
Identify objects (e.g., sun, birds, airplanes, moon) in the sky
Explain why the sun can only be seen in the daytime, but the moon can be seen sometimes during the day and sometimes at night
Describe how the sun provides light and heat to warm the earth (e.g., land, air, and water)
Explain how the moon appears slightly different every day, but looks nearly the same every four weeks
Explain how stars are like the Sun, but because they are at a great distance, they look like small points of light
Solar System
Identify components of our solar system (e.g., planets, moons, Sun)
Identify the basic characteristics (e.g., composition, rings) of objects (e.g., planets, sun, small bodies) in the solar system
The Universe
Identify tools that are used to study the universe (e.g., telescopes, space probes, satellites, space craft)
Identify the characteristics of the Earth (i.e., spherical in shape, orbits the Sun, rotates on tilted axis)
Identify the objects in the sky that have predictable patterns of movement (e.g., sun, planets, moons, stars)
Identify characteristics of stars (e.g., color, size, temperature, life cycle)
Identify the composition (e.g., stars, galaxies) and scale of the universe
Explain the relationship between the Big Bang Theory and the origin and evolution of the universe
Explain how the Sun and other stars are powered by nuclear reactions (e.g., the fusion of hydrogen to form helium, formation of elements)
Characteristics of the Earth
Explain how rocks are formed (e.g., melting, cooling, metamorphism, combinations of minerals)
Describe the characteristics of the layers of the Earth (i.e., crust, mantle, core)
Identify the Earth's renewable and nonrenewable resources (e.g., solar, wind, fossil fuels, water, soil, metals)
Explain how phenomena on Earth (i.e., day, year, seasons, lunar phases, eclipses, tides) are related to the position and motion of the Sun, Moon, and Earth
Geologic Processes
Understand the rock cycle
Explain the water cycle
Explain how landforms are changed (e.g., crustal deformation, volcanic eruption, deposition, weathering, erosion)
Identify evidence for plate tectonics theory (e.g., fit of continents, location of earthquakes, volcanoes, mid-ocean ridge, plate boundaries)
Identify a variety of methods (e.g., rock sequences, fossil correlation, radiometric dating) used to determine geologic time
Explain the changes Earth has undergone over geologic time (e.g., fossil record, plate tectonics, climate change, glaciation)
Earth's History
Relate the changes in the Earth's atmosphere to the evolution of photosynthetic life forms
Energy in the Earth System

Explain how energy in the Earth system is governed by convection, conduction, and radiation (e.g., heat moves in the Earth's mantle by convection, conduction occurs along the mid-oceanic ridges, energy from the Sun reaches the Earth through radiation)
Explain how Earth systems are in dynamic equilibrium (e.g., cycling of energy and matter through the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere)
Geologic Processes, Human Activities, and the Environment
Identify the short-term and long-term effects of physical processes (e.g., plate tectonics, extreme weather phenomenon) on the environment and society
Analyze how evidence of past natural hazards and geologic events has predicted subsequent hazards and events (e.g. Gap time method to predict earthquakes and tsunamis)
Explain the effects of human activities (e.g., dams, levees, farming practices, deforestation, land-use practices, landmanagement strategies) on the environment
Explain the short-term and long-term effects of chemical processes (e.g., acid rain, CO2 emissions, ozone depletion, run-off) on the environment and society
Standard 6: Students understand relations between science and technology.
Forms of Technology
Identify natural objects that differ from those made by humans (e.g., rock-brick, sun-light bulb)
Identify tools (e.g., scissors, pencil, hammer) that can be helpful or harmful
Identify tools/inventions (e.g., computer, car, cell phone) that impact the way we live
Identify tools (e.g., ruler, hand lens, thermometer, balance) that are used to observe, measure, and investigate things they could not otherwise see, measure and do
Explain how models (e.g., plastic animal figures, skeletal models) can be used to understand science
Technological Design
Use several steps to complete a task (e.g., building blocks, art project, group investigation)
Identify ways technology (e.g., zippers, Velcro, measuring instruments, computers) can be used to solve problems at home and school
Evaluate the effects of technology on people and the environment (e.g., new construction, oil drilling, electric cars)
Explain how an invention may lead to other inventions
Use technology to design a solution to a problem
Evaluate a product or design using established criteria
Identify examples of how technologies have evolved
Design a product or solution to a problem given constraints (e.g., limits of time, costs, materials and environmental factors)
Explain the relationship between science and technology
Use appropriate technologies and techniques to solve a problem (e.g., computer-assisted tools, Internet, research skills)

Explain how scientific principles have been used to create common technologies (e.g., household appliances, automotive parts, agricultural equipment, textiles, fabrics, computers, Internet resources, CD-ROMs)
Select and use appropriate technologies, tools, and techniques to solve a problem (e.g., computer-assisted tools, Internet, research skills, CBL, graphing calculators)
Identify examples of how new technologies advance science
Technology and Society
Identify ways in which technology has influenced the course of history and improved the quality of life
Identify technologies (e.g., communication, agriculture, information processing, transportation) that are influenced by societies
Identify intended benefits and unintended consequences that result from the development and use of technologies
Explain how emerging technologies (e.g., genetic manipulation, biofuels, and hydrogen fuels) may impact society and the environment
Explain how designing and implementing technology requires weighing trade-offs between positive and negative impacts on humans and the environment
Standard 7: Students understand relations between science and personal, social, and environmental issues.
Science and Personal Health
Identify safety rules for school and home
Identify personal care practices (e.g., dental care, hand washing, exercise, nutrition) that contribute to a healthy life
Identify personal choices (e.g., personal hygiene, nutrition, fitness, safety) that contribute to individual wellness
Describe some things (e.g., UV Rays, secondhand smoke, pollution) from our environment that are harmful to people
Identify ways to prevent the spread of germs.
Identify risks or benefits of personal health choices (e.g., tobacco, alcohol, prescription and illegal drugs, fast foods)
Explain how science affects personal health (e.g., injury prevention, immunization, organ transplant, medical scanning devices)
Identify the factors (e.g., pollution, heredity, diet, virus, bacteria, parasite) that may result in disease.
Explain how personal health is related to fitness, substance abuse, sexual activity, and nutrition
Science and Environmental Issues
Describe ways that humans influence their environment (e.g., littering, recycling, car pooling)
Identify the benefits of recycling, reusing, and reducing
Identify consequences of natural and humaninduced environmental changes (e.g., erosion, tsunami, deforestation)
Explain ways humans benefit from Earth's resources (e.g., air, water, soil, food, fuel, building materials)
Explain how natural hazards affect populations, resources, and the environment (e.g., floods, storms, hurricanes, volcanoes, earthquakes)
Explain how recycling and conservation affect populations, resources, and the environment
Explain how overpopulation affects organisms, resources, and environments (e.g., depletion of food resources, habitat availability, increased loss due to disease, parasites and predators
Identify factors that affect populations (e.g., food webs, carrying capacity, overpopulation, disease, food supply, algal blooms, resources, conservation practices)

Explain the impact of environmental laws and policies on the environment and society (e.g., waste/pollutants from industry, carbon dioxide emissions, location and number of animals in a feedlot versus water supply)
Explain ways renewable and nonrenewable resources are managed (e.g., land reclamation, forest management, CRP, hunting licenses, energy â€“conserving technologies)
Explain the economic and social impact of using alternative energy resources
Science and Social Issues
Identify ways in which science and technology have greatly improved human lives (e.g., food quality and quantity, transportation, health, sanitation, communication)
Explain the impact of science on food technology (e.g., preservatives, packaging, genetically modified organisms)
Explain the interaction of science and technology with social issues (e.g., mining, natural disasters)

Explain how science and technology can influence personal, industrial, and cultural decision-making (e.g., organ transplants, cloning, stem cell research, genetic manipulation, use of genetic profile, archeological discoveries, land management, resource management)

text: Standard 8: History and Nature of Science

children.text: Standard 8: Students understand the history and nature of science.
People in Science
Explain why anyone can be a scientist
Identify ways (e.g., create things, ask questions, make observations, figure things out) that everybody can do science
Identify ways scientists work together to solve problems (e.g., share results, teamwork, investigate)

Identify ways people of all ages, genders, and backgrounds use science in their careers and in daily life (e.g., children check temperature conditions to decide what to wear, farmer uses genetic grains, hikers use GPS, depth-finder in boat, hearing-aides for disabilities)
Identify a variety of careers in the field of science
Identify various settings in which scientists may work alone or in a team (e.g., industries, laboratories, field work)
Explain how science is influenced by human qualities (e.g., reasoning, insightfulness, creativity, life-long learning)
Identify the role of scientists in theoretical and applied science (e.g., careers, employment possibilities)
Identify the human characteristics that influence scientific advancement (e.g., intellectual honesty, openness, objectivity, curiosity, skepticism, ethical conduct, cooperation)
Explain how individuals and groups, from different disciplines in and outside of science, contribute to science at different levels of complexity
Scientific Knowledge
Identify scientific advances that changed popular beliefs (e.g., Earth was center of universe, world was flat, man was incapable of flight)
Explain why results of similar scientific investigations may turn out differently (i.e., inconsistencies in methods, materials, and observations)
Identify scientific advances that have resulted in new ideas and further advance
Explain the importance of keeping clear and accurate records of scientific investigations (e.g., Darwin's research, DaVinci's notebooks, Galileo's notes, Goodall's observations)
Explain how many people from various cultures have made important contributions to the advancement of science and technology
Identify theories that have changed over time (e.g., alchemy, atomic structure, model of the solar system)

Identify the criteria that scientific explanations must meet to be considered valid (e.g., must be based on consistent and repeatable data, be consistent with experimental and observational evidence about nature, make accurate predictions about systems being studied, be logical, report methods and results, be open to question and reexamination, respect rules of evidence)
Science and Society
Explain how views and attitudes have influenced the development of science (e.g., religion, previous knowledge, cultural tradition, superstition, folklore, legends)
